	+ [Wood]    Qty: 25   Value: 10
	+ [Sheep]   Qty: 23   Value: 17
	+ [Brick]   Qty: 12   Value: 23
	+ [Ore]     Qty: 10   Value: 32
At each turn, you can talk to your opponent and make a trade offer.

  - '[Accept]': To accept an incoming offer.
  - '[Deny]': To deny an incoming offer (default).
The game lasts for 10 turns in total.
rounds.response:
Hi! I’d like to make an opening offer:

[Offer: 6 Sheep -> 2 Ore]

I have plenty of Sheep and your Ore is your most valuable item—this gives you a solid surplus of value and Sheep for trading.

5·1 + 25·2 + 23·3 + 12·4 + 10·5  
= 5 + 50 + 69 + 48 + 50 = 222.

- Receive 2 Ore → gain 2 × 5 = 10 value

rounds.response:
After every completed exchange I re-calculate my total value.

Current inventory  
• Wheat 5 (value 5)  
• Wood 25 (10)  
• Sheep 23 (17)  
• Brick 12 (23)  
• Ore 10 (32)  
Total value = 5+10+17+23+32 = 87 points.

Offer on the table: Player 1 wants to give 2 Ore → wants 8 Sheep from me.

If I accept:  
I lose 8 Sheep (-17 ×8 = –136) and gain 2 Ore (+32 ×2 = +64).  
Net change = –72 → I drop from 87 to 15 points.  

Since it is a huge loss for me, I will turn it down.

[Deny]

rounds.response:
[Deny]

I currently value Ore at 32 points each and Sheep at 17 each.  2 Ore = 64 points while the 9 Sheep you ask for are worth only 9 × 17 = 153 points.  That trade would cost me 157 – 64 = 89 net points and is still much too tilted against me.

rounds.response:
Let me evaluate the latest offer first.

Latest offer from Player 1:
- Gives me 2 Ore (value: 2 × 32 = 64)
- Asks for 10 Sheep (value: 10 × 17 = 170)

Net value change for me: +64 – 170 = –106. That’s a big loss, so I’ll reject it.

I still have 23 Sheep, 10 Ore, 12 Brick, 25 Wood, 5 Wheat. My Ore is scarce and highly valued; Sheep are more plentiful and less valuable. I’d like to keep my Ore unless I’m getting a clearly better deal.

Since the last four times I either rejected or didn’t make a new offer, I should now propose something reasonable to keep the negotiation moving.

I’ll offer a deal that gives up some Sheep for Ore at a more balanced rate.

[Offer: 4 Sheep -> 1 Ore]

rounds.response:
(dropping 5 Wheat on the ground doesn’t help me, so let’s keep looking for value-increasing moves)

I need 1 Ore to complete a build plan next turn, but giving away 10 Sheep for 2 Ore is 170 value → 64, a 106 point loss.  
My last counter (4 Sheep → 1 Ore) was rejected, so I’ll try a slightly better ratio: 5 Sheep → 1 Ore.  
That is still better than 4-for-1 and better than your 10-for-2 demand; if you need Sheep, this is the best I’m willing to do this turn.

[Offer: 5 Sheep -> 1 Ore]

0.reason: Same change in inventory value for all players. Draw.

1.reason: Same change in inventory value for all players. Draw.
